step1: This is step 1
step2: This is step 2
step3: This is step 3
step4: This is step 4
step5: This is step 5

name: Heart attack
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Help person sit down and rest in comfortable position
step3: Loosen tight clothing around neck and waist
step4: Ask if they have prescribed heart medication
step5: Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR if needed

name: Cardiac arrest
step1: Check responsiveness and breathing
step2: Call emergency services or instruct someone to call
step3: Begin chest compressions immediately - push hard and fast
step4: Use AED if available - follow voice prompts
step5: Continue CPR until help arrives or signs of life return

name: Chest pain (angina)
step1: Call emergency services if pain is severe or worsening
step2: Help person rest in comfortable position
step3: Assist with prescribed angina medication if available
step4: Loosen tight clothing around chest and neck
step5: Monitor vital signs until help arrives

name: Difficulty breathing
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Help person sit upright in comfortable position
step3: Loosen tight clothing around neck and chest
step4: Stay calm and reassure the person
step5: Monitor breathing pattern and be ready for CPR if needed

name: Asthma attack
step1: Call emergency services if breathing doesn't improve quickly
step2: Help person use their inhaler if available
step3: Have person sit upright and lean forward slightly
step4: Loosen tight clothing around neck and chest
step5: Monitor breathing and stay with person until help arrives

name: Severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Use epinephrine auto-injector if available
step3: Help person lie down with legs elevated
step4: Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR
step5: Stay with person until emergency help arrives

name: Choking (adult)
step1: Ask if person is choking - if can't speak, act immediately
step2: Perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver)
step3: Continue thrusts until object is dislodged
step4: If unconscious, begin CPR
step5: Call emergency services if object not dislodged quickly

name: Choking (child)
step1: Check if child can cough or speak
step2: Perform back blows between shoulder blades
step3: Perform chest thrusts if back blows don't work
step4: Call emergency services if object not dislodged
step5: Begin CPR if child becomes unconscious

name: Drowning
step1: Remove person from water safely
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Check breathing and responsiveness
step4: Begin CPR if not breathing
step5: Keep person warm and monitor until help arrives

name: Hyperventilation
step1: Stay calm and speak reassuringly
step2: Have person sit down in quiet area
step3: Encourage slow, deep breathing
step4: Do not use paper bag method
step5: Seek medical help if symptoms persist or worsen

name: COPD flare-up
step1: Call emergency services if breathing severely affected
step2: Help person use prescribed inhalers or nebulizer
step3: Assist person to sit upright in comfortable position
step4: Loosen tight clothing around chest
step5: Monitor breathing and stay with person

name: Severe respiratory infection
step1: Call emergency services for breathing difficulty
step2: Help person sit upright for easier breathing
step3: Provide humidified air if possible
step4: Monitor breathing pattern and oxygen levels
step5: Keep person warm and comfortable

name: Carbon monoxide poisoning
step1: Move person to fresh air immediately
step2: Call emergency services
step3: Check breathing and responsiveness
step4: Begin CPR if not breathing
step5: Do not re-enter contaminated area

name: Stroke
step1: Use FAST test: Face, Arm, Speech, Time to call emergency
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Keep person comfortable with head elevated
step4: Do not give food, drink, or medication
step5: Monitor breathing and note symptom onset time

name: Seizure (convulsion)
step1: Call emergency services if seizure lasts over 5 minutes
step2: Clear area of hard or sharp objects
step3: Place something soft under head
step4: Do not restrain or put anything in mouth
step5: Roll onto side after seizure ends and monitor breathing

name: Febrile seizure (children)
step1: Place child on soft surface on their side
step2: Do not restrain child or put anything in mouth
step3: Time the seizure duration
step4: Call emergency services if seizure lasts over 5 minutes
step5: Cool child gently after seizure ends

name: Fainting (syncope)
step1: Check responsiveness and breathing
step2: Position person flat on back with legs elevated
step3: Loosen tight clothing around neck and waist
step4: Do not give food or drink until fully alert
step5: Seek medical attention if fainting recurs

name: Head injury (minor)
step1: Apply ice pack to reduce swelling
step2: Monitor for signs of concussion
step3: Keep person awake and monitored for first few hours
step4: Watch for vomiting, confusion, or worsening headache
step5: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen

name: Concussion
step1: Call emergency services for severe symptoms
step2: Keep person still and calm
step3: Apply cold compress to head if no bleeding
step4: Monitor breathing and consciousness level
step5: Do not give medication without medical advice

name: Traumatic brain injury (severe)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Keep person still and support head/neck
step3: Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR
step4: Do not remove helmet if present
step5: Control any bleeding with gentle pressure

name: Unconscious person (unknown cause)
step1: Check responsiveness and breathing
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Place in recovery position if breathing
step4: Begin CPR if not breathing
step5: Look for medical alert jewelry or identification

name: Severe bleeding (arterial/venous)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Apply direct pressure to wound with clean cloth
step3: Elevate injured area above heart level
step4: Add more layers if blood soaks through
step5: Keep person still and warm until help arrives

name: Nosebleed
step1: Have person sit upright and lean forward
step2: Pinch soft part of nose for 10-15 minutes
step3: Apply ice pack to bridge of nose
step4: Do not tilt head backward
step5: Seek medical help if bleeding continues after 20 minutes

name: Deep cuts / lacerations
step1: Apply direct pressure to control bleeding
step2: Clean wound with running water if possible
step3: Cover with sterile dressing
step4: Seek medical attention for deep wounds
step5: Watch for signs of infection

name: Puncture wound
step1: Allow wound to bleed briefly to clean itself
step2: Clean with running water and mild soap
step3: Apply antibiotic ointment if available
step4: Cover with sterile dressing
step5: Seek medical attention for tetanus shot if needed

name: Amputation (finger/limb)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Control bleeding with direct pressure
step3: Elevate injured area
step4: Wrap amputated part in clean, damp cloth and place in plastic bag
step5: Keep amputated part cool but do not freeze

name: Internal bleeding (suspected)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Keep person lying flat and still
step3: Monitor breathing and consciousness
step4: Keep person warm with blanket
step5: Do not give food or drink

name: Gunshot wound
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Apply direct pressure to bleeding areas
step3: Do not remove embedded objects
step4: Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR
step5: Keep person still and warm until help arrives

name: Stab wound
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Do not remove embedded object
step3: Apply pressure around wound, not on object
step4: Monitor breathing and consciousness
step5: Keep person still and warm

name: Animal bites (dog, cat)
step1: Control bleeding with direct pressure
step2: Clean wound thoroughly with soap and water
step3: Apply antibiotic ointment if available
step4: Cover with sterile dressing
step5: Seek medical attention for rabies risk and infection

name: Minor burns (first degree)
step1: Cool burn with cool running water for 10-15 minutes
step2: Do not use ice or butter on burn
step3: Apply aloe vera or burn cream if available
step4: Cover loosely with sterile non-stick dressing
step5: Watch for signs of infection

name: Moderate burns (second degree)
step1: Cool burn with cool running water for 10-20 minutes
step2: Do not break blisters
step3: Cover loosely with sterile non-stick dressing
step4: Elevate burned area if possible
step5: Seek medical attention for proper treatment

name: Severe burns (third degree)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Do not remove burned clothing stuck to skin
step3: Cover burn loosely with sterile non-stick dressing
step4: Elevate burned area if possible
step5: Monitor for shock and breathing difficulties

name: Electrical burns
step1: Ensure power source is off before touching person
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Check breathing and responsiveness
step4: Cover burns with sterile dressing
step5: Monitor for cardiac issues - be ready for CPR

name: Chemical burns
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Brush off dry chemicals before flushing
step3: Flush with cool running water for 15-20 minutes
step4: Remove contaminated clothing carefully
step5: Cover loosely with sterile dressing

name: Sunburn (severe)
step1: Move to shaded or indoor area immediately
step2: Apply cool compresses or take cool bath
step3: Apply aloe vera or moisturizing lotion
step4: Drink plenty of water to prevent dehydration
step5: Seek medical help for blisters, fever, or severe pain

name: Smoke inhalation
step1: Move person to fresh air immediately
step2: Call emergency services
step3: Check breathing and responsiveness
step4: Begin CPR if not breathing
step5: Monitor for respiratory distress until help arrives

name: Fracture (broken bone)
step1: Keep injured area still and supported
step2: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling
step3: Elevate injured limb if possible
step4: Do not try to straighten or realign bone
step5: Seek medical attention for proper treatment

name: Dislocation
step1: Keep injured area still and supported
step2: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling
step3: Do not try to put joint back in place
step4: Seek immediate medical attention
step5: Monitor circulation beyond injury site

name: Sprain
step1: Rest injured area
step2: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth for 15-20 minutes
step3: Use compression bandage to reduce swelling
step4: Elevate injured area above heart level
step5: Seek medical help if severe pain or unable to bear weight

name: Strain
step1: Rest injured muscle
step2: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth for 15-20 minutes
step3: Use compression bandage if helpful
step4: Elevate injured area if possible
step5: Apply heat after 48 hours for muscle relaxation

name: Spinal injury
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Keep person still - do not move unless absolutely necessary
step3: Support head and neck in position found
step4: Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR
step5: Do not remove helmet if present

name: Pelvic injury
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Keep person still and do not move them
step3: Monitor breathing and circulation
step4: Keep person warm with blanket
step5: Do not give food or drink

name: Crushed limb
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Do not remove crushing object if recently applied
step3: Control bleeding with direct pressure
step4: Keep person still and warm
step5: Monitor breathing and consciousness

name: Swollen joint (possible infection/injury)
step1: Rest injured joint
step2: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth for 15-20 minutes
step3: Elevate injured area above heart level
step4: Use compression bandage if helpful
step5: Seek medical attention for proper diagnosis

name: Rib fracture
step1: Help person find comfortable breathing position
step2: Apply ice pack to injured area
step3: Encourage shallow breathing to prevent pneumonia
step4: Seek medical attention for proper diagnosis
step5: Monitor for breathing difficulties

name: Road accident (vehicle collision)
step1: Ensure scene is safe before approaching
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Check all involved persons for responsiveness
step4: Do not move injured persons unless in immediate danger
step5: Provide first aid for visible injuries until help arrives

name: Bike or scooter crash
step1: Ensure scene is safe before approaching
step2: Check person's responsiveness and breathing
step3: Do not remove helmet unless necessary for breathing
step4: Stabilize head and neck if spinal injury suspected
step5: Call emergency services for serious injuries

name: Fall from height
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Do not move person unless absolutely necessary
step3: Stabilize head and neck in position found
step4: Monitor breathing and consciousness
step5: Control any visible bleeding with direct pressure

name: Heavy object falling on person
step1: Ensure scene is safe before approaching
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Check responsiveness and breathing
step4: Do not remove object if still crushing
step5: Provide first aid for visible injuries

name: Workplace machinery injury
step1: Turn off machinery immediately if safe to do so
step2: Call emergency services
step3: Do not remove person from machinery if trapped
step4: Control bleeding with direct pressure
step5: Monitor breathing and consciousness until help arrives

name: Getting trapped (hand in machine, etc.)
step1: Turn off power to machinery immediately
step2: Call emergency services and fire department
step3: Do not try to force person free
step4: Keep person calm and still
step5: Monitor breathing and provide reassurance

name: Glass injury
step1: Apply direct pressure around the wound to control bleeding, but be careful to avoid pushing any glass fragments deeper into the injury.
step2: Do not attempt to remove large or deeply embedded pieces of glass. Removing them can cause severe bleeding and further tissue damage.
step3: If there are small, surface-level glass pieces, carefully clean the area around the wound with clean, running water to prevent infection.
step4: Cover the injury with a sterile dressing or a clean cloth. If glass is protruding, build up padding around the object without pressing on it.
step5: Seek immediate medical attention for proper wound care, including safe glass removal, stitches if needed, and a tetanus shot if necessary.

name: Elevator/staircase fall
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Do not move the person unless they are in immediate danger of further harm from their current location.
step2: Keep the person still and stabilize their head and neck in the position you found them. This is crucial to prevent worsening a potential spinal injury.
step3: If there is bleeding, control it by applying firm pressure with a clean cloth or bandage. Avoid moving the person to do this if it risks spinal injury.
step4: Monitor the person's breathing and level of consciousness closely until help arrives. Talk to them calmly to keep them reassured.
step5: Do not give the person any food, water, or medication, as this could complicate medical treatment once emergency services arrive.

name: Sports injury (severe)
step1: Stop all activity immediately. Do not allow the injured person to 'walk it off' or continue playing, as this can make the injury much worse.
step2: Apply an ice pack wrapped in a thin cloth to the injured area for 15-20 minutes to reduce swelling and numb the pain. Do not apply ice directly to the skin.
step3: If it's a limb injury, compress the area with an elastic bandage. Make sure it is snug but not so tight that it cuts off circulation.
step4: Elevate the injured area above the level of the person's heart, if possible. This uses gravity to help reduce swelling and throbbing.
step5: Seek medical attention for a proper diagnosis. A professional needs to rule out fractures, torn ligaments, or other serious damage that requires specific treatment.

name: Electric shock
step1: Ensure the power source is turned off before you touch the person. If you cannot turn it off, use a dry, non-conductive object like a wooden broom handle to move the person away from the source.
step2: Call emergency services immediately. Electric shocks can cause hidden internal injuries and serious heart problems, even if the person seems fine.
step3: Check if the person is breathing and responsive. Look, listen, and feel for breaths. Gently tap their shoulder and ask loudly, 'Are you okay?'
step4: If the person is not breathing, begin CPR immediately. Push hard and fast in the center of the chest. If an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is available, use it as soon as possible.
step5: Once the person is safe, look for and treat any visible burns. Cover them with a sterile, non-stick dressing. Do not use blankets or towels that might stick to the wound.

name: Lightning strike
step1: Ensure the scene is safe from further lightning risk. Do not become a victim yourself. If the storm is still active, move to a safe, enclosed building or a hard-topped vehicle.
step2: Call emergency services immediately. A lightning strike can cause cardiac arrest, neurological damage, and severe burns that require urgent medical care.
step3: Check the person's breathing and responsiveness. Lightning often causes the heart to stop. It is safe to touch them immediately; they do not retain an electrical charge.
step4: If the person is not breathing, begin CPR immediately. They have a high chance of survival if CPR is started promptly. Continue until medical help takes over.
step5: Treat the person for any visible burns, fractures, or other injuries. Be aware that they may also have hearing or vision problems and be confused or unconscious.

name: Extreme heatstroke
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Heatstroke is a life-threatening condition that can damage the brain and other internal organs and requires urgent medical treatment.
step2: Move the person to a cool, shaded, or air-conditioned area immediately. The priority is to lower their core body temperature as quickly as possible.
step3: Remove any excess or tight clothing. This helps the body cool down through evaporation and improves air circulation over the skin.
step4: Cool the person rapidly using whatever methods are available. Use a cool water spray, wet cloths, or a cool bath. Gently fan them to speed up evaporation.
step5: Monitor the person's breathing and consciousness closely. If they have a seizure, ensure they are in a safe space and do not put anything in their mouth.

name: Hypothermia
step1: Call emergency services for severe hypothermia. This is a critical medical emergency where the body loses heat faster than it can produce it.
step2: Move the person to a warm, dry place as gently as possible. Jarring movements can trigger a dangerous irregular heartbeat in a severely hypothermic person.
step3: Remove any wet clothing carefully and cut it away if necessary. Replace it with warm, dry layers of clothing or blankets, covering their head and neck.
step4: If the person is conscious and able to swallow, provide warm, sweet, non-alcoholic drinks. Do not give them alcohol or caffeine, as these can worsen heat loss.
step5: Monitor their breathing closely. A person with severe hypothermia may breathe very slowly and faintly. Be prepared to perform CPR if their breathing stops.

name: Frostbite
step1: Move the person to a warm area immediately to prevent further heat loss and worsening of the frostbite.
step2: Remove any wet clothing, jewelry, or tight items from the affected area carefully, as these can restrict blood flow.
step3: Warm the frostbitten area gently by soaking it in warm (not hot) water or using body heat. Avoid direct heat from stoves or heating pads.
step4: Do not rub or massage the frostbitten area, as this can cause further damage to the skin and tissues.
step5: Seek medical attention for severe frostbite, as it can lead to permanent tissue damage and requires professional treatment.

name: Avalanche burial
step1: Call emergency services with the precise location of the avalanche. Provide as much detail as possible to guide rescuers.
step2: Use avalanche transceivers (beacons) to locate the buried person quickly. Move systematically and follow the signal to their position.
step3: Clear the person's airway immediately once they are found. Remove snow from around their mouth and nose to allow them to breathe.
step4: Check their breathing and begin CPR if they are not breathing. Time is critical, so start resuscitation efforts without delay.
step5: Treat the person for hypothermia and other injuries once they are breathing. Keep them warm and monitor their condition until help arrives.

name: Tornado/storm injury
step1: Ensure the scene is safe from further danger, such as falling debris, downed power lines, or ongoing severe weather.
step2: Call emergency services immediately to report the incident and request medical assistance for the injured person.
step3: Check all persons for responsiveness and breathing. Provide assistance to those who are unconscious or struggling to breathe.
step4: Provide first aid for visible injuries, such as bleeding or fractures, while waiting for professional help to arrive.
step5: Move to a safe shelter if further storms are approaching. Ensure everyone is protected from additional harm.

name: Structural collapse injury
step1: Ensure the scene is safe before approaching. Look for unstable structures, gas leaks, or electrical hazards that could cause further harm.
step2: Call emergency services and the fire department to report the collapse and request specialized rescue teams.
step3: Do not move debris that may be stabilizing the structure, as this could cause further collapse and endanger trapped individuals.
step4: Check the breathing of trapped persons and provide first aid if accessible. Reassure them and keep them calm while waiting for rescue.
step5: Monitor trapped persons until rescue arrives. Provide updates to emergency responders about their condition and location.

name: Food poisoning
step1: Stop eating the suspected food immediately to prevent further ingestion of harmful bacteria or toxins.
step2: Drink small amounts of clear fluids, such as water or oral rehydration solutions, to stay hydrated and replace lost electrolytes.
step3: Rest and avoid solid foods until symptoms subside. Gradually reintroduce bland foods like crackers or toast once feeling better.
step4: Seek medical help if symptoms are severe, such as persistent vomiting, high fever, or signs of dehydration.
step5: Save a sample of the suspected food if possible, as it may help identify the cause and prevent others from getting sick.

name: Alcohol poisoning
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Alcohol poisoning is a medical emergency that requires professional intervention.
step2: Do not leave the person alone. Stay with them and monitor their condition closely until help arrives.
step3: If the person is unconscious but breathing, place them in the recovery position to prevent choking on vomit.
step4: Keep the person warm with a blanket, as alcohol can lower body temperature and increase the risk of hypothermia.
step5: Do not give coffee or try to make the person vomit, as this can worsen dehydration or lead to aspiration.

name: Drug overdose (accidental)
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Provide details about the suspected substance and the person's condition.
step2: Check the person's breathing and responsiveness. Look for signs of slow or shallow breathing and unresponsiveness.
step3: If the person is unconscious but breathing, place them in the recovery position to maintain an open airway.
step4: Begin CPR if the person is not breathing. Continue until medical help arrives or the person shows signs of life.
step5: Keep medication containers or evidence of substance use to show responders. This can help them provide appropriate treatment.

name: Household chemical ingestion
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Provide details about the chemical ingested, if known.
step2: Do not induce vomiting unless instructed by a medical professional, as this can cause further damage to the throat and digestive tract.
step3: Keep the chemical container to show responders. This helps them identify the substance and determine the best treatment.
step4: Monitor the person's breathing and consciousness. Be prepared to provide CPR if their breathing stops.
step5: If the chemical is on the skin or clothes, remove contaminated clothing and rinse the area with water for at least 15 minutes.

name: Bleach poisoning
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Bleach is highly corrosive and can cause severe internal damage.
step2: Do not induce vomiting, as this can cause the bleach to burn the throat and esophagus a second time.
step3: If the person is conscious and able to swallow, give small sips of water or milk to dilute the bleach and soothe the throat.
step4: Keep the bleach container to show responders. This helps them assess the concentration and potential damage.
step5: Monitor the person's breathing and be ready to perform CPR if they become unresponsive or stop breathing.

name: Pesticide poisoning
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Pesticides can be highly toxic and require urgent medical attention.
step2: If the pesticide was inhaled, move the person to fresh air immediately to reduce further exposure.
step3: If the pesticide is on the skin, remove contaminated clothing and rinse the skin with water for at least 15 minutes.
step4: Keep the pesticide container to show responders. This helps them identify the active ingredients and provide appropriate treatment.
step5: Monitor the person's breathing and be prepared to perform CPR if they become unresponsive or stop breathing.

name: Acid/alkali exposure
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Chemical burns can cause deep tissue damage and require professional care.
step2: Brush off any dry chemicals from the skin before flushing with water. This prevents the chemical from spreading or reacting further.
step3: Flush the affected area with cool running water for at least 15-20 minutes to dilute and remove the chemical.
step4: Remove contaminated clothing carefully while flushing to avoid spreading the chemical to other areas of the body.
step5: Cover the area loosely with a sterile dressing after flushing. Avoid using towels or blankets that may stick to the wound.

name: Gas leak inhalation
step1: Move the person to fresh air immediately to prevent further inhalation of the toxic gas.
step2: Call emergency services and the gas company to report the leak and request assistance.
step3: Check the person's breathing and responsiveness. Look for signs of respiratory distress or unconsciousness.
step4: Begin CPR if the person is not breathing. Continue until medical help arrives or the person shows signs of life.
step5: Do not turn electrical switches on or off, as this could create a spark and ignite the gas, causing an explosion.

name: Poisonous plant exposure (poison ivy, etc.)
step1: Wash the affected area with soap and water immediately to remove the plant's oils and reduce the severity of the reaction.
step2: Remove contaminated clothing carefully to avoid spreading the oils to other parts of the body or surfaces.
step3: Apply calamine lotion or hydrocortisone cream to soothe itching and reduce inflammation.
step4: Take an antihistamine if needed to relieve itching and allergic reactions. Follow the dosage instructions on the package.
step5: Seek medical help if the reaction is severe, such as widespread rash, facial swelling, or difficulty breathing.

name: Poisoning by spoiled food
step1: Stop eating the spoiled food immediately to prevent further ingestion of harmful bacteria or toxins.
step2: Drink small amounts of clear fluids, such as water or broth, to stay hydrated and help flush out toxins.
step3: Rest and avoid solid foods until symptoms like vomiting and diarrhea subside.
step4: Seek medical help if symptoms are severe, such as high fever, bloody stools, or signs of dehydration.
step5: Save a sample of the suspected food if possible, as it may help identify the cause and prevent others from getting sick.

name: Unknown toxin exposure
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Provide as much information as possible about the situation and the person's symptoms.
step2: Move the person to fresh air if the exposure is suspected to be from an airborne toxin.
step3: Remove contaminated clothing if it is safe to do so, and rinse the skin with water if the toxin is on the body.
step4: Monitor the person's breathing and consciousness closely. Be prepared to perform CPR if their breathing stops.
step5: Keep any suspicious materials, such as containers or substances, to show responders for identification and treatment.

name: Snake bite (venomous)
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Provide details about the snake's appearance if possible, but do not attempt to capture it.
step2: Keep the person calm and still to slow the spread of venom through the bloodstream. Avoid unnecessary movement.
step3: Position the bite area below the level of the heart to reduce venom circulation.
step4: Remove any tight clothing or jewelry near the bite site, as swelling may occur rapidly.
step5: Do not cut the wound or use a suction device, as these methods are ineffective and can cause further harm.

name: Bee/wasp sting (severe reaction)
step1: Call emergency services immediately if the person shows signs of a severe allergic reaction, such as difficulty breathing or swelling of the face.
step2: Use an epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen) if the person has one and you are trained to use it.
step3: Remove the stinger by scraping it out with a flat object like a credit card. Avoid squeezing the stinger, as this can release more venom.
step4: Apply a cold compress to the sting site to reduce swelling and pain.
step5: Monitor the person's breathing closely and be prepared to perform CPR if they become unresponsive or stop breathing.

name: Spider bite (dangerous species)
step1: Call emergency services if the person shows severe symptoms, such as difficulty breathing, muscle cramps, or a spreading rash.
step2: Keep the person calm and still to slow the spread of venom. Avoid unnecessary movement.
step3: Wash the bite area with soap and water to reduce the risk of infection.
step4: Apply a cold compress to the bite to reduce pain and swelling.
step5: Try to safely identify the spider or take a photo for medical professionals, but do not attempt to capture it.

name: Scorpion sting
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Scorpion stings can be life-threatening, especially to children and the elderly.
step2: Keep the person calm and still to slow the spread of venom. Avoid unnecessary movement.
step3: Wash the sting area with soap and water to reduce the risk of infection.
step4: Apply a cold compress to the sting site to reduce pain and swelling.
step5: Monitor the person's breathing and be prepared to perform CPR if they become unresponsive or stop breathing.

name: Jellyfish sting
step1: Get the person out of the water immediately to prevent further stings and ensure their safety.
step2: Rinse the affected area with seawater, not fresh water, as fresh water can trigger the release of more venom.
step3: Carefully remove any tentacles with tweezers or a gloved hand to avoid further stings.
step4: Apply vinegar or a baking soda paste to the sting site to neutralize the venom and reduce pain.
step5: Seek medical help if the person shows signs of a severe reaction, such as difficulty breathing or intense pain.

name: Shark attack
step1: Get the person out of the water immediately to prevent further injury and ensure their safety.
step2: Call emergency services immediately. Shark attacks often cause severe bleeding and tissue damage.
step3: Control bleeding by applying direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage.
step4: Treat the person for shock by keeping them warm and lying flat with their legs elevated, if possible.
step5: Monitor the person's breathing and be prepared to perform CPR if they become unresponsive or stop breathing.

name: Rat bite (risk of infection)
step1: Wash the wound thoroughly with soap and water for at least 5 minutes to reduce the risk of infection.
step2: Apply an antibiotic ointment if available to further prevent infection.
step3: Cover the wound with a sterile dressing to protect it from dirt and bacteria.
step4: Seek medical attention to assess the risk of infections like tetanus or rat-bite fever.
step5: Watch for signs of infection, such as redness, swelling, pus, or fever, and seek further medical help if they occur.

name: Mosquito-borne fever emergency
step1: Call emergency services if the person shows severe symptoms, such as high fever, confusion, or difficulty breathing.
step2: Keep the person comfortable and hydrated. Encourage them to drink water or oral rehydration solutions.
step3: Monitor their temperature and breathing closely. Look for any changes in their condition.
step4: Use cool compresses to help reduce fever and make the person more comfortable.
step5: Provide information about recent travel to doctors, as this can help identify the specific illness and guide treatment.

name: Stray dog attack
step1: Move to a safe area away from the attacking animal to prevent further injury.
step2: Control bleeding by applying direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage.
step3: Clean the wounds thoroughly with soap and water to reduce the risk of infection.
step4: Cover the wounds with a sterile dressing to protect them from dirt and bacteria.
step5: Seek medical attention to assess the risk of rabies and other infections, and to receive proper wound care.

name: Diabetic emergency – low blood sugar (hypoglycemia)
step1: Look for symptoms like confusion, sweating, shaking, or unconsciousness, which indicate low blood sugar.
step2: If the person is conscious, give them a fast-acting sugar source like fruit juice, soda, or glucose tablets.
step3: If the person is unconscious, do not give them anything by mouth, as this could cause choking.
step4: Call emergency services if the person does not improve within 15 minutes or if their condition worsens.
step5: Monitor their breathing and be prepared to perform CPR if they become unresponsive or stop breathing.

name: Diabetic emergency – high blood sugar (hyperglycemia)
step1: Call emergency services if the person shows severe symptoms, such as confusion, rapid breathing, or unconsciousness.
step2: Monitor their breathing and consciousness closely. Look for any changes in their condition.
step3: Do not give insulin unless it is prescribed to the person and you are trained to administer it.
step4: If the person is conscious, encourage them to drink water to help flush out excess sugar through urine.
step5: Be prepared to perform CPR if the person becomes unresponsive or stops breathing.

name: High fever (adult)
step1: Take the person's temperature to confirm the fever and assess its severity.
step2: Use cool compresses or a lukewarm bath to help reduce the fever and make the person more comfortable.
step3: Encourage the person to drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration.
step4: Use fever-reducing medication like acetaminophen or ibuprofen if appropriate and following dosage instructions.
step5: Seek medical help if the fever persists for more than a few days, is very high, or is accompanied by other severe symptoms.

name: High fever (child)
step1: Take the child's temperature to confirm the fever and assess its severity.
step2: Use cool compresses or a lukewarm bath to help reduce the fever and make the child more comfortable.
step3: Encourage the child to drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration.
step4: Use age-appropriate fever medication like acetaminophen or ibuprofen, following dosage instructions carefully.
step5: Seek immediate medical help if the fever is very high, the child has a seizure, or they show signs of dehydration.

name: Severe dehydration
step1: Call emergency services immediately. Severe dehydration can lead to organ failure and requires urgent medical attention.
step2: Have the person sip small amounts of water or an oral rehydration solution slowly to replenish fluids and electrolytes.
step3: Keep the person in a cool, shaded area and loosen any tight clothing to help regulate their body temperature.
step4: Monitor their breathing and level of consciousness closely. Look for signs of confusion or worsening condition.
step5: Be prepared to perform CPR if the person becomes unresponsive or stops breathing while waiting for help to arrive.

name: Heat exhaustion
step1: Move the person to a cool, shaded or air-conditioned area immediately to prevent progression to heatstroke.
step2: Have them lie down and elevate their legs slightly to improve blood circulation to vital organs.
step3: Provide cool water or sports drinks to sip slowly, helping to rehydrate and replace lost electrolytes.
step4: Apply cool, wet cloths to their skin or mist them with water to help lower their body temperature.
step5: Seek medical help if symptoms do not improve within 30 minutes or if they show signs of heatstroke like confusion or fainting.

name: Sudden abdominal pain (unknown cause)
step1: Call emergency services if the pain is severe, worsening, or accompanied by fever, vomiting, or rigid abdomen.
step2: Help the person find a comfortable position, usually lying on their back with knees bent to relieve tension.
step3: Do not give any food, drink, or pain medication as this could mask symptoms or complicate medical treatment.
step4: Monitor their breathing and consciousness level closely for any changes while waiting for help.
step5: Be ready to inform medical responders about the pain's location, intensity, and any other symptoms observed.

name: Appendicitis symptoms
step1: Call emergency services immediately for suspected appendicitis, as it requires urgent medical or surgical intervention.
step2: Help the person lie down in a comfortable position, often on their back with knees drawn up to ease pain.
step3: Do not provide any food, drinks, or pain relievers, as these can interfere with diagnosis and treatment.
step4: Monitor their temperature and pain level closely, noting any changes or worsening of symptoms.
step5: Provide medical professionals with details about symptom onset, pain location, and any other relevant health information.

name: Severe vomiting
step1: Help the person sit up or lean forward while vomiting to maintain a clear airway and prevent choking.
step2: Offer small, frequent sips of clear fluids or oral rehydration solutions once vomiting subsides.
step3: Apply a cool compress to their forehead or back of neck to help reduce nausea and provide comfort.
step4: Seek medical attention if vomiting persists for hours, contains blood, or is accompanied by severe pain.
step5: Watch for signs of dehydration such as dry mouth, dizziness, or decreased urination and seek care if needed.

name: Diarrhea with dehydration risk
step1: Encourage drinking oral rehydration solutions or clear fluids to replace lost water and electrolytes.
step2: Avoid dairy, fatty foods, caffeine, and sugary drinks which can worsen diarrhea symptoms.
step3: Ensure the person rests and monitor their hydration status for signs like thirst or dark urine.
step4: Seek medical help if severe dehydration signs appear, such as sunken eyes, rapid heartbeat, or confusion.
step5: Watch for alarming symptoms like blood in stool or high fever which may indicate a serious infection.

name: Severe infection symptoms (sepsis early signs)
step1: Call emergency services immediately if sepsis is suspected - it's a life-threatening response to infection.
step2: Monitor the person's breathing and mental status closely for confusion, slurred speech, or extreme sleepiness.
step3: Keep the person warm with blankets to manage potential shock and prevent hypothermia.
step4: Do not give any food or drink as they may need emergency surgery or could aspirate if consciousness declines.
step5: Be prepared to provide responders with information about recent illnesses, injuries, or medical history.

name: Pregnancy emergency (bleeding, pain)
step1: Call emergency services immediately for any significant bleeding or severe abdominal pain during pregnancy.
step2: Help the pregnant person lie on their left side to improve blood flow to both mother and baby.
step3: Monitor bleeding closely and save any passed tissue for medical examination.
step4: Keep the person calm and comfortable while waiting for emergency responders to arrive.
step5: Provide medical teams with pregnancy details including gestational age and any previous complications.

name: Childbirth emergency (delivery in progress)
step1: Call emergency services immediately and clearly state that a baby is being delivered.
step2: Help the mother into a comfortable position, typically lying back with knees bent and feet flat.
step3: Gather clean towels, blankets, and supplies for the delivery and to receive the baby.
step4: Support the baby's head as it emerges but do not pull - let the mother's pushing do the work.
step5: Once delivered, keep the baby warm on the mother's chest and ensure the airway is clear.

name: Getting locked in a closed room/area
step1: Stay calm and assess your surroundings for alternative exits, ventilation sources, or communication options.
step2: Check for windows, vents, or service panels that might provide an escape route or way to signal for help.
step3: Use a mobile phone to call for assistance, providing your exact location and situation details.
step4: Make noise to attract attention by knocking on walls, shouting, or using objects to create sound.
step5: Conserve energy and air if in a confined space by sitting down and breathing slowly and deeply.

name: Panic attack
step1: Remain calm and use a reassuring tone to help the person feel safe and supported.
step2: Move to a quieter, less stimulating environment if possible to reduce overwhelming sensations.
step3: Guide them through slow, deep breathing exercises - inhaling through nose and exhaling through mouth.
step4: Stay with the person throughout the episode, offering steady presence and reassurance.
step5: Seek medical assistance if the attack is severe, prolonged, or accompanied by chest pain or fainting.

name: Hyperventilation episode
step1: Stay calm and speak in a reassuring manner to help reduce the person's anxiety and panic.
step2: Have them sit down in a quiet area to minimize distractions and help them focus on breathing.
step3: Encourage slow, controlled breathing patterns - inhaling deeply and exhaling slowly.
step4: Do not use a paper bag for breathing as this can be dangerous and is no longer recommended.
step5: Seek medical help if breathing doesn't normalize, or if chest pain, dizziness, or fainting occurs.

name: Foreign object stuck in eye, nose, or ear
step1: Do not use tweezers, cotton swabs, or other instruments that could push the object deeper or cause injury.
step2: For eye: Flush with clean, lukewarm water using an eyecup or gentle stream from a faucet if it's a small particle.
step3: For nose: Have the person blow their nose gently once. If unsuccessful, seek medical help rather than trying further.
step4: For ear: Tilt the head to the affected side and gently shake. Let gravity help dislodge the object if possible.
step5: Seek professional medical attention if the object remains lodged, causes pain, or vision/hearing is affected.
